answer_html: Either of these would be a counter-example, so the statement is false.

hints_html: To get some intuition, think of the most basic polynomials first and see if the property holds.
hints_latex:
To get some intuition, think of the most basic polynomials first and see
if the property holds.
hints_raw: To get some intuition, think of the most basic polynomials first and see if the property holds.
question: 2 (d)
sols_html:
Polynomials are functions like lines, parabolas, cubics, etc. The best examples to consider are horizontal lines and parabolas.

  • No horizontal line crosses the x-axis.

  • The graph of a parabola can be shifted so that it doesn’t cross the x-axis.

Either of these would be a counter-example, so the statement is false.
sols_raw:
Polynomials are functions like lines, parabolas, cubics, etc.  The best examples to consider are horizontal lines and parabolas.  

* No horizontal line crosses the ''x''-axis. 

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 2d horizontal line.jpg|200px]]

* The graph of a parabola can be shifted so that it doesn't cross the ''x''-axis.  

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 2d parabola.jpg|200px]]

Either of these would be a counter-example, so the statement is false.
statement_html:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If \(f(x)\) is a polynomial, then its graph crosses the \(x\)-axis.
statement_latex:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is
true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If $f(x)$ is a polynomial, then its graph crosses the $x$-axis.
statement_raw:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If <math>f(x)</math> is a polynomial, then its graph crosses the <math>x</math>-axis.
